div.note: At this, Don Abbondio, who had struggled to answer less pointed questions, was left speechless.

And, to tell the truth, even I—manuscript before me and pen in hand, contending only with words and fearing only the criticism of my readers—even I feel a certain reluctance to go on. For there is something unsettling about this effortless deploying of so many fine exhortations: to fortitude and charity, to diligent caring for others and boundless self-sacrifice.
But when I realize that all this was said by a man who actually practiced them, I forge bravely ahead.
“You have nothing to reply?” asked the Cardinal.
“Ah, if you had only done what charity and duty demanded of you. No matter how things ended, you wouldn’t be standing here now without an answer.
See for yourself what you’ve done: You heeded the call of evil rather than the demands of duty. You heeded it promptly.

Evil appeared before you to issue its orders but wished to remain concealed from those who could have guarded against it and protected themselves. It didn’t want anyone to know. It wanted secrecy, so it could be at liberty to nurture its schemes of treachery and violence. It ordered you to transgress and keep silent: You transgressed and did not speak.
“Now I am asking if there is more. Admit if you made up excuses for refusing to marry the young couple in order to conceal the true reason.”
Here he paused, still waiting for an answer.

“The bigmouths must have reported that to him, too,” thought Don Abbondio, but he gave no sign of having something to say, so the Cardinal went on. “If it’s true that you lied to those poor children and kept them in the dark, ignorant, right where evil wanted them…then you leave me no choice but to believe it.
All I can do now is feel your shame and hope that you will grieve with me.
Look where your attachment to worldly things has led you. (Good God! And you’re still using it as an excuse.)
It has led you—and feel free to dispute what I’m saying if I seem unjust; and if I do not, take my words as a salutary humbling—it has led you to deceive the weak and lie to your children.”

“So that’s the way of the world,” said Don Abbondio to himself. “That hellion”—he meant the Nameless One—“is welcomed with open arms. And me, all because of one white lie, which I told only to save my skin, I am subjected to this reproach.
But they’re our superiors, and our superiors are always right.
My fate is to be pilloried with criticism from all sides, even from holy men.” Speaking aloud he said, “I was wrong. I know I was wrong. But under the circumstances what was I supposed to do?”
“You still ask?
Haven’t I told you?
Should I even have had to tell you?
You were supposed to love, my son. To love and to pray.

Then you would have known that evil might issue threats and strike blows, but it cannot command. You should have joined together, in accordance with the laws of God, what man wanted to put asunder. You should have administered to those unhappy innocents the sacrament they had every right to ask of you. God Himself would have kept you safe from the consequences, since you would have been following His path; but since you took another path, you are responsible for your own safety, and look at the consequences!
Did you have no human defenses? Did you see no way out? Did you look for one, think of one, attempt one?
If your poor charges had been married, they would have found a way out by themselves. They were ready to escape from the tyrant’s reach and had already chosen a place of refuge.
But even if they hadn’t, did it not occur to you that you had a superior?
A superior who, for all the world, would not have the authority to reprimand you for failing in your duties, unless he also had the obligation to help you to fulfill them?
Why did you not think to inform your bishop of the impediment that a sinister violence had placed on the exercise of your ministry?”

“Perpetua’s very words!” thought Don Abbondio irritably. Throughout that long speech, the most vivid image to appear before him was that of the two bravi, together with the thought that Don Rodrigo was alive and well and, sooner or later, would return in glory and triumph and fury.

And although the Cardinal’s dignity, demeanor, and language filled him with confusion and fear, his fear neither overwhelmed him nor ultimately persuaded him to change his ways, since, in his mind, the Cardinal wielded no musket, no sword, and no bravi.

“How did you not realize,” the Cardinal continued, “that if no other refuge was available to those poor oppressed innocents, I was always there to welcome them and get them to safety if you had sent them to me, sent the forsaken to a bishop as his children, not as a share of his burden but as a precious share of his riches?
As for you, I would have been anxious for you. I wouldn’t have been able to sleep until I was certain that not a hair on your head would be harmed.
Did you not realize that I had the means to keep you safe?

As for that boldest of men, did you not realize that his audacity would have evaporated the minute he found out that his schemes were known far away from here, that they were known to me, that I was following them, resolved to defend you using every means in my power?
Did you not realize that, while men are frequently inclined to make promises they cannot keep, by the same token they threaten far more than they actually attempt?
Did you not realize that evil is rooted not only in its strength but also in the credulity and terror of others?”

“The very things that Perpetua said,” Don Abbondio thought again when he heard this, without reflecting that the agreement between his servant and Federigo Borromeo on what he could and should have done spoke volumes against him.

“But you,” the Cardinal continued and concluded, “did not see and did not want to see anything other than your own temporal danger. Small wonder, then, that it seemed so great to you that you neglected everything else for its sake.”
“It’s because I am the one who saw those faces,” Don Abbondio blurted out. “I am the one who heard their words.
It’s easy for Your Grace to speak, but put yourself in the shoes of a poor priest who found himself in that spot.”

The moment he uttered these words, he bit his tongue. He realized that he’d let his irritation get the better of him, and said to himself, “Now I’ll have the devil to pay!” But as he cast a dubious look upward, he was amazed to see in that man—whose thoughts he could never guess or understand—to see, as I was saying, his stern expression of reprimand soften to something more remorseful and pensive.
“Unfortunately,” said Federigo, “such is our miserable and terrifying condition.

Only God knows whether we ourselves are ready to offer what we must demand rigorously from others: We must judge, correct, reprimand. And only God knows what we ourselves would have done in such an instance, what we have done in similar instances!
But I would be wrong to use my weakness as the measure of other men’s duties, as the standard for my teaching!
Yet I must undoubtedly not only teach others, but also set an example, unlike the scribes and pharisees, who lay heavy burdens on other men’s shoulders, and will not lift a finger to help them.

And so, my son and brother, since others know the errors of those in authority better than they do themselves, if you feel I have been negligent in my duties—out of cowardice or in any respect—tell me so frankly, make me mend my ways. So that, if I have failed to set an example, I can at least make a confession.

Reproach me freely for my weaknesses. Then the words I speak will carry more value, since you will hear more vividly that they do not belong to me, but rather to He who gives both you and me the strength we need to do what those words prescribe.”

“Oh, what a holy man! But how he torments not just me,” thought Don Abbondio, “but also himself. For not only must I wrack my brain, and criticize and interrogate myself, but so must he.” Then he said aloud, “Your Grace, you must be joking.
Who does not know the fortitude, the tireless zeal of your illustrious Lordship?”
And he added to himself, “All too well!”
“I was not seeking your praise, which makes me tremble,” said Federigo, “for God knows my shortcomings. The ones I know myself are already enough to humble me.
But I would have liked—I would like—for us to be humbled together before Him, to pray together.
I would like, out of my love for you, for you to understand how contrary your behavior was, and how contrary your language is, to the laws which you preach, and by which you shall be judged.”

“So it’s all my fault,” said Don Abbondio. “But these people who reported me to you, didn’t they tell you how they snuck into my house through treachery, to catch me off guard and contract a marriage against the rules?”

“They did tell me, my son. But it pains me, it saddens me, that you are still making excuses; that you want to excuse yourself by accusing others; and that the substance of that accusation should instead be part of your confession.
But who instilled in them, not the need, but rather the temptation to do so?

Would they have attempted that unlawful means if the legitimate one had not been barred to them? Attempted to trick their pastor if he had instead welcomed them with open arms, helped them, counseled them? Tried to surprise him, if he had not hidden from them?
And you would blame them for this? Indignant that, after so much misfortune—what am I saying?—that in the midst of their misfortune, they poured out their hearts to their and your pastor?
While the world may not want to hear the appeals of the oppressed, the complaints of the afflicted, but does that mean that we should not?
And what good would it have done you if they had remained silent?
Did you not consider that their case in its entirety will be judged by God?

Is there not yet another reason to love them (and you already have so many), in the fact that they have given you the chance to hear the sincere voice of your bishop, given you the means to see more clearly and atone, in part, for your great debt toward them?
Even if they had provoked you, offended you, tormented you, I would still tell you (would I have to?) to love them for this very reason.

To love them because they have suffered, because they still suffer, because they are your children, because they are weak, because you need forgiveness, and their prayers will help you immensely to receive it.”
Don Abbondio was quiet. But it was no longer a forced, impatient silence. He was quiet like a man who has more to ponder than to say.
The words he had just heard were unexpected consequences, and new applications, of a doctrine he had studied long ago, but which was still present, undisputed, in his mind.
The suffering of others—which he’d always ignored because of fear for himself—appeared to him in a new way.

And although he did not feel the full remorse that the sermon had sought to instill in him (since that same fear was always there to defend him), he still felt it. He felt a certain disappointment in himself, a compassion for others, a mix of tenderness and humiliation.

It was—if such a comparison can be allowed—like the damp broken wick of a candle that, presented to the flame of a large torch, initially smokes, sputters, and crackles, wanting nothing to do with it, but in the end, for better or worse, catches fire and burns.
He would have beat his breast and wept were it not for the thought of Don Rodrigo. Still, he showed himself to be moved enough for the Cardinal to realize that his words had not been wasted.

“Now,” the Cardinal continued, “the boy is a fugitive from his home, the girl is about to leave hers, and both have strong reasons for staying away, with no prospect of ever being reunited here, only hoping that God will reunite them elsewhere. Now, unfortunately, they don’t need you. And you, unfortunately, have no chance to help them. Nor in our own limited view do I see any such possibility in the future.
But who knows whether God in his mercy will provide you with such an opportunity?
If He does, do not miss the opportunity! Seek it out, be vigilant, pray to Him to give you other chances.”
“I shall not fail, Your Grace. Truly, I shall not fail,” replied Don Abbondio in a voice which, in that moment, came straight from the heart.
“Oh, yes, my son, yes!” exclaimed Federigo. And with affectionate dignity, he concluded, “Heaven knows I would rather have spoken with you about other things.

Both of us have already lived long lives. Heaven knows how hard it was for me to burden your old age with such reprimands, and how much happier I would have been for us to console each other over our common cares, our troubles, by speaking of the blessed hope that is so near to us both.
May it please God that the words I have spoken today shall help us both.
Do not behave in such a manner that on the Day of Judgment, I will have to account for having kept you in an office at which you had failed so miserably.
Let us redeem the time, for midnight is near and the bridegroom cannot tarry. Let us keep our lamps lit.

Let us present our poor wretched hearts to God, so that He may fill them with His love, which atones for the past and safeguards the future, which fears and trusts, weeps and rejoices, with wisdom, and which always becomes the virtue we so sorely need.”
At this he stood up to leave, and Don Abbondio followed after him.

— At this point the anonymous author advises us that this was not their only conversation, nor was Lucia their only subject, but that he had limited himself to this part of it, to avoid digressing too much from the main story.

And that, for the same reason, he would not mention other notable things that Federigo said during his visit, nor his generosity, the disagreements patched up, the feuds between individuals, families, and entire territories that were either settled or briefly suppressed (which was far more frequent, unfortunately), nor the bringing to heel of a bravo or petty tyrant, for his entire life or just a short spell. Things that always occurred, to a greater or lesser extent, in every part of the diocese where that excellent man would visit.
He does go on to tell us that, the next morning, Donna Prassede arrived at the appointed time to fetch Lucia and pay her respects to the Cardinal, who praised the girl and recommended her warmly.

Lucia took leave of her mother—you can imagine her tears—and departed from her home. For the second time she bid farewell to her village, with that sense of double bitterness that one feels in leaving a place that was singularly beloved and can no longer be so.

But she had not said her last goodbye to her mother, since Donna Prassede wished to stay a few more days at her villa, which was not very far. And Agnese promised her daughter that she would stop by, so they might wish each other an even sadder farewell.
The Cardinal was also ready to continue his tour when who should arrive for a word with him but the pastor of the parish to which the Nameless One’s castle belonged.

After being shown in, he presented a purse and a letter from the nobleman, asking Federigo to persuade Lucia’s mother to accept the one hundred gold scudi in the purse, to be used as a dowry for the girl, or for whatever purpose she thought best. At the same time, he asked the Cardinal to tell them that, if they were ever in need of a favor, the poor girl knew where to find him, unfortunately, and that for him it would be a most welcome opportunity.
The Cardinal immediately sent for Agnese and relayed the message, which she heard with equal parts pleasure and surprise. And he gave her the purse, which she accepted without too much fuss.
“May God bless that gentleman,” she said, “and I thank Your Eminence so, so much.
Please don’t say anything to anyone, because in a village like this…You’ll have to forgive me, please understand.
I know that a man of your class doesn’t go around gossiping about these things, but…I’m sure you understand.”

She went home, quietly quietly. She locked herself in her room and opened the purse, but nothing could have prepared her for the sight of so many shiny new coins—all in a pile and all hers. She had never seen more than one at a time, and even then, only rarely. She counted them, struggling to stack them up neatly together, since they kept bulging out and slipping through her inexpert fingers. Once she finally managed to get them in a neat pile, she wrapped a rag around it, tied the bundle up tightly with string, and tucked it into a corner of her straw mattress.
For the rest of the day, all she did was mull things over, daydreaming, making plans for the future, and longing for the days to come.
After turning in for the night, she remained awake for a spell, her thoughts keeping company with the coins on which she was lying. After she fell asleep, she saw them in her dreams.
At dawn, she got up and set off immediately for the villa where Lucia was staying.
For her part Lucia, although no less reluctant to bring up the issue of her vow, was determined to embark on a conversation with her mother that would be their last for many months.

As soon as they were alone, Agnese began, her face animated and her voice low, as if someone might be eavesdropping on them. “I have some wonderful news,” and she told Lucia about their unexpected luck.
“May God bless him,” said Lucia. “This way you’ll be comfortable, and you can also do good for someone else.”
“What?” exclaimed Agnese. “Don’t you see the many things we can do with all that money?
Listen. The only person I have in the world is you—and let me add, Renzo, since I’ve considered him like a son ever since the two of you started seeing each other.
I only hope nothing bad’s happened to him, since he’s never sent word. Who says everything has to turn out for the worse, anyway?
All we can do is hope.
As for me, I’d have liked to lay my bones to rest in my own village, but now that you can’t live there, thanks to that scoundrel…the very thought of him being nearby makes me hate it.
From the start, I was ready to accompany the two of you to the ends of the earth. And I always have been. But without money, how could we manage?
Now do you understand?

The pittance that our poor boy was able to scrape together through a lot of hard work and a lot of scrimping, well, in came justice and swept it all away. But, to make up for it, the Lord has sent us some good fortune.
So, when Renzo figures out a way to let us know he’s alive, and his whereabouts, and his intentions, I’ll come myself to fetch you in Milan.
Once upon a time, it would have felt like a long way, but adversity brings out the mettle in us. I’ve been as far as Monza, and I know what it’s like to travel.

I’ll take a sensible man along with me, a relative, like Alessio from Maggianico, since, to be honest, there’s slim pickings around here. I’ll come with him, and pay all the expenses, and…Are you following me?”
Seeing that Lucia, rather than cheering up, was becoming gloomy, and showing only a joyless tenderness, Agnese stopped what she was saying and asked, “Child, what’s wrong? Don’t you agree?”
“My poor Mamma!” exclaimed Lucia, throwing her arms around Agnese’s neck and burying her face in her bosom.
“What’s the matter?” asked her mother anxiously.
“I should have told you before,” replied Lucia, lifting her face and drying her tears, “but I didn’t have the heart. Have pity on me!”
“Come now, tell me what it is.”
“I can no longer be that poor boy’s wife!”
“What? What are you saying?”

Lucia, with her head lowered and her breast heaving, sobbing without tears, like a person describing something, no matter how regrettable, that cannot be changed, revealed the story of her vow. At the same time, clasping her hands together, she begged her mother’s forgiveness for not having spoken till then. She begged her not to tell a living soul, and to help her keep her vow.
Agnese was shocked and dismayed.

She wanted to take offense at being kept in the dark, but thoughts of this grave situation overcame her resentment. She wanted to say, “What have you done?” but it would have been like raging at heaven, especially when Lucia started to describe that night in the most vivid colors: the deep despair and the unexpected liberation in which the vow had been made so explicitly, so solemnly.

While she spoke, Agnese remembered the various examples of strange and terrible punishments inflicted when a vow was broken that she had heard told over and over, and which she herself had told her daughter.
After a few moments in stunned silence, she asked, “What will you do now?”
“Now,” replied Lucia, “it’s up to God. It’s up to God and the Blessed Mother.

I have placed myself in their hands. They have not forsaken me yet, and they will not forsake me now that…The grace that I am asking of God, the only grace, after the salvation of my soul, is that He bring me back to you again. And He will grant me this, I know He will.
That day…in that carriage…Oh Blessed Virgin!…Those men!…Who could have believed that they were taking me to the man who, in the end, would bring me back to you the next day?”
“But not to tell your mother of this vow right away!” scolded Agnese, with an annoyance tempered by affection and pity. “Try to understand.
I didn’t have the heart…and what good would it have done to trouble you with this earlier?”
“And Renzo?” asked Agnese, shaking her head.
“Ah!” exclaimed Lucia with a start. “I mustn’t think about that poor boy any more.
You can see that it wasn’t meant to be…It’s as if God Himself wanted to keep us apart.
And who knows…? But no, no. He will have shielded him from harm, and will bring him better luck, without me.”
“But in the meantime,” her mother resumed, “if you hadn’t gone and made that vow, and all the rest, and if nothing bad has happened to Renzo, then I could have fixed everything with that money.”
“But would the money have even come to us,” replied Lucia, “if I hadn’t experienced that night?
God is the one who wanted things to turn out this way. His will be done.”
At this she broke down in tears.
Her unexpected argument left Agnese speechless.

After a few moments, Lucia, swallowing her tears, picked up where she had left off. “What’s done is done. Now we have to accept it wholeheartedly. And you, poor Mamma, you can help me, first by praying to God for your poor daughter, and then…that poor boy will have to be told.
Could you take care of it, please, since you are able?

When you find out where he is, have someone write to him, find a man…maybe your cousin Alessio, who’s so prudent and charitable. He’s always been fond of us, and he’ll keep it to himself. Have him write down what happened, where I was taken, how I suffered, that this was God’s will, and that he should resign himself, and that I can never ever belong to anyone.
And break it to him gently, explain that I made a promise, that I took a vow.
When he learns that I promised Our Lady…he’s always had the fear of God in him.
And as soon as you have news of him, have someone write to me, let me know he’s safe. And then…tell me nothing more.”
Touched by these words, Agnese assured her daughter that everything would be done as she wished.
“I have something else to tell you,” Lucia continued. “If that poor boy hadn’t had the misfortune of setting his mind on me, none of this would have happened to him.
Now he’s wandering the world. They cut off his livelihood. They took away his belongings, the money he had set aside, poor boy.
You know why…And now we have so much!

Oh, Mamma! Since the Lord has sent us so much abundance, and that poor boy—you really did treat him as your own…yes, as your own son. The two of you should split the money between you, since God will surely not abandon us.
Look for a safe opportunity and send him the money. Heaven knows how much he needs it!”
“Do you think I wouldn’t?” replied Agnese. “Of course I’ll send it to him.
Poor boy!
Why do you think I was so happy to get the money?
Well, I never…! I was happy as could be on my way here.
Never mind. I’ll send it to him, poor Renzo! But him, too…Listen to me. People who need money are happy to get it, but this money isn’t going to make Renzo any better off.”

Lucia thanked her mother for her prompt and generous acquiescence with a gratitude and an affection that would make any observer feel that Renzo still had a claim on her heart, perhaps more than she herself realized.
“How am I supposed to manage without you, my poor girl?” said Agnese with tears of her own.
“And I without you, my poor mamma? In the house of strangers? And down there in Milan…!
But the Lord will be with us both, and then He will reunite us.
In eight or nine months we’ll see each other again. And by then, and hopefully sooner, He will have arranged things so we can be together.
Let’s leave it in His hands.
And I will keep praying and praying to Our Lady to bestow this grace upon us.
If I had anything more to offer her, I would. But she is so merciful that she will grant it to me for nothing.”

With these and other similar, repeated words of lament and reassurance, of regret and resignation, with many exhortations to say nothing and many promises not to, with many tears, and after long and renewed embraces, the women went their separate ways, each promising the other that they would meet again the following autumn at the latest. As if keeping the promise depended on them, but that is what people always say in such cases.
— Weeks went by, and Agnese couldn’t find out anything about Renzo.
No letter or message from him reached her, and none of her acquaintances in the village and its environs knew any more than she did.

She was not the only one to search for him in vain. Cardinal Federigo, who was not making an empty promise when he told the poor women that he would look into what had happened to the poor boy, had in fact written immediately for information.

Back in Milan, he received a reply, telling him that the whereabouts of the person in question had not been found; that he had actually stayed for a while at a relative’s house, in a certain village, where he had not drawn attention to himself; but one morning, he had suddenly disappeared, and not even his relative knew where he was, and could only repeat certain vague and contradictory rumors, that the youth had enlisted for the Levant, crossed over to Germany, and drowned while fording a river; and that he would keep an eye out, and if more concrete news appeared, it would immediately be shared with His Most Illustrious and Reverend Eminence.
Later, these rumors and others also spread to the territory of Lecco, and consequently came to the attention of Agnese.

The poor woman struggled to figure out what was true and get to the bottom of the different versions, but she could never get past affirmations of “People say” that, even nowadays, are considered adequate proof of many things.
Sometimes, no sooner had she been told one story than another person would come by to say it was all lies, only to offer her a tale that was equally strange and sinister in exchange.
But it was all gossip. Now for the facts:

The Governor of Milan and Captain-General of Italy, Don Gonzalo Fernández de Córdoba, made a commotion with the Resident of Venice to Milan, because a crook, a known scoundrel, a promoter of looting and murder—the notorious Lorenzo Tramaglino, who had incited a riot in order to escape from the grips of justice—had received welcome and hospitality in the territory of Bergamo.
The Resident replied that it came as news to him, and that he would write to Venice in order to provide His Excellency with whatever explanation of the case was found.

In Venice, they made it a policy to support and encourage the inclination of Milanese silk-workers to move to the territory of Bergamo, and thus they assured that there were many benefits to doing so, particularly the one that mattered the most: security.

In a dispute between two mighty litigants, however, a third person, no matter how small, has to pay the price. So Bortolo was warned secretly (it is not known by whom), that Renzo was not safe in his village, and should look for work at another factory, and also change his name for a while.

Bortolo took the hint, asked no further questions, and ran to tell his cousin. He picked him up in a carriage and drove him to another silk-maker, about fifteen miles away, where he introduced him as Antonio Rivolta to the proprietor, an old acquaintance, who was also from the state of Milan.
Although it was a lean year, the man did not have to be asked twice to hire a worker who had been recommended to him as honest and skilled by an upright person who knew the business.

And when the new employee was put to the test, the proprietor had nothing but praise for him. Except for one thing: He thought the youth a bit dim-witted at first, since whenever he called out, “Antonio,” he didn’t always get an answer.

Shortly after, the Bergamo police commissioner received an order from Venice, delivered in a mild manner, telling him to collect and provide information on whether a certain subject was to be found in his jurisdiction, specifically in a certain town.

The Captain, having done his duty to the best of his understanding, transmitted a negative reply, which was then transmitted to the Resident in Milan, who had it transmitted to the Grand Chancellor so that he might transmit it to Don Gonzalo Fernández de Córdoba.
There was no shortage of busybodies who wanted to know from Bortolo why the young man was no longer there, and where he had gone.
To the first question Bortolo would reply, “Well, he just disappeared.”

To placate the more insistent, and keep them from suspecting the truth, he thought it best to mention one or the other of the reports mentioned above. But he professed no certainty, saying he was only repeating hearsay, and had no concrete proof.

But when he was asked the same question on behalf of the Cardinal—whose name was not divulged—with certain trappings of importance and mystery, insinuating that the interested party was a great personage, Bortolo became especially suspicious, and deemed it necessary to give his usual response. Indeed, since he was dealing with a great personage, he spit out—all in one go—every single one of the rumors he himself had spread on every previous occasion.

But don’t go imagining that a man of Don Gonzalo’s stature held any kind of grudge against that poor little silk-worker from the mountains; or that, having learned of his lack of respect toward, and the awful words addressed to, his coat of arms, the one showing a Moorish king with chains around his neck, he wanted to retaliate; or that he thought Renzo was so dangerous that he needed to be pursued as a fugitive, and not be allowed to live even in exile (as the Roman Senate did with Hannibal).

Don Gonzalo had far more important things on his mind than to concern himself with Renzo’s doings. And if he appeared to, it was only because, through a unique set of circumstances, without meaning to, or even realizing it (at the time or later), the poor boy found himself linked, by a very thin and invisible thread, to too many and too important things.
